$R£E VERSE: Verse which does not conform to any definite presecribed metrical
pattern. Free verse Is characterised by a much less definite rhythm than is
found in regular metrical verse. However, it utilizes other techniques of
poetry such as alliteration and consonance.
IAMBIC FOOT: A metrical foot consisting of an unaccented syllable. It is the
most common metrical measure in English verse. Example:” A slumber did
my spirit seal,- I had no human fears^WLlliam Wbrdsworth.
IAMBIC ROTAMETER: A line of verse consisting of five lambic ffet. Example:
‘*3hen flashed the living lightning from her eyes..."—Alexander Rope
IAMBIC TETRAMETER: A line of verse consisting of four iambic feet. Example:
"Eie woods are lovely, dark, and deep... "—Robert Frost.
IMAGERY:
IMAGIST SCHOOL OF POETRY; A group of American poets prominent in the early
twentieth century. Most coaspicious in the Imagist movement were H.D. (Hilda
Doolittle), Amy Jewell, Carl Sandburg, and Robert Frost. Amy Lowell’s
Tendencies in Modern African Poetsy (l£17) sets forth the major objectives
of the movement: (1) to use the exact word, not the nearly exact; (2) to
avoid all overworked cliche expressions; (3) to create new rhythms, not to
copy old rhythms; (k) to allow absolute freedom in the choice of subject;
(5) to create firm, definite pictures, to present a clear image; (6) to consider
concentration as the very essence of poetry; (7) to suggest rather than state
completely.
IMPERFECT RHYME: Approximate rhyme. Example: lover and rover; seal and fill.
Imperfect rhymes are not necessarily an indication of poetic carelessnesTbut
may be deliberately constructed to produce a special effect.
MASOrmiE ENDING;
PARADCK: A statement which, although superficially corrfcradlcotiy or absurd, may
in a deeper sense be true.
QUATRAIN: A stanza consisting of four verses.
